head.supplied: Melbourne bot. Garden ¶ 25/3/65 ¶ ¶ It was, dear Professor Parlatore, my intention to write to you very fully on many subjects by this mail; but an unusual pressure of work & manyfold detentions forb...

div.p: It was, dear Professor Parlatore, my intention to write to you very fully on many subjects by this mail; but an unusual pressure of work & manyfold detentions forbid my doing so at the close of the post-hour. Allow me therefore but briefly to mention, that a large case with algae has been sent pr "Great Britain" for you to the Italian Consul at Liverpool. They are but crudely dried, but after remaceration they will give thousands of specimens. I added some medicinal resins and barks. By this mail I forwarded to the Italian Consul at Alexandria between 4-500 seedlings of Araurcaria Cunninghami & the 4th vol. of my Fragmenta & the 2. vol. of plants of Victoria (illustrations only) also some seeds, fresh collected of Eucalyptus Globulus. I have sent several lots of black Swans by various opportunities & will continue until your Government has about 100, so that this fine bird may be fully naturalized. Freight as far as London & Alexandria is always free. Emus are difficult to get but I have recently sent two, also some Kangaroos. If you desire it, I can send for your Museum some prepared quadrupeds & birds & insects from here. When the distribution of dried plants takes place this winter I shall not forget your establishment at Florence.
A small work on the plants of the Chatham Islands I sent a little while ago.
I am engaged in aiding for a search after poor Dr. Leichhardt. I hope it will be successful and make besides the great western half of Australia known.
Allow me, dear Professor to remain, with cordiality
